title: How to Make Millet Flour Pellets from Millet Flour

steps.headline: Hand-process the millet flour.
steps.description: Set out two large bowls, (traditionally calabash gourds), a generous cup of water and a spoon or other hard edge as available for scraping the sides of the bowl as flour accumulates.

steps.headline: Set aside a portion of dry millet flour to be added back in as the pellets form, to keep them from sticking.
Dribble water into the millet flour.
steps.description: Work it through the flour to spread the dampness. Scoop and turn your hand through the flour; doing this automatically forms the pellets. Add water and dry flour alternately, to dampen all of the flour.

steps.headline: Choose the pellet size needed.
steps.description: The millet flour develops a variety of pellet sizes. Millet couscous is a steamed recipe, requiring smaller pellets, but boiled porridges require larger pellets because they are less likely to disintegrate during the boiling process. The process of dampening, breaking up clumps and adding dry flour to keep the formed pellets from sticking must be repeated until all the millet flour has been converted to uniformly-sized millet-flour pellets.

steps.headline: Scrape off flour from the bowl edges.
steps.description: During this process, the millet flour will adhere to the calabash gourd walls, so scrape this off. Note: Metal bowls usually do not develop a build-up.

steps.headline: Finish up and make use of the millet pellets.
steps.description: In this case, only one size of pellet is required, so there are no sifting steps required. This process has produced in less than one hour of steady hand-working, about 5 kg of millet flour pellets suitable for a popular West African millet porridge. These millet pellets are ready to be sent to the kitchen to boil, put in the refrigerator (up to a week) or frozen for use some other day.

text: Hand-process the millet flour. Set out two large bowls, (traditionally calabash gourds), a generous cup of water and a spoon or other hard edge as available for scraping the sides of the bowl as flour accumulates. Set aside a portion of dry millet flour to be added back in as the pellets form, to keep them from sticking.  Dribble water into the millet flour. Work it through the flour to spread the dampness. Scoop and turn your hand through the flour; doing this automatically forms the pellets. Add water and dry flour alternately, to dampen all of the flour. Choose the pellet size needed. The millet flour develops a variety of pellet sizes. Millet couscous is a steamed recipe, requiring smaller pellets, but boiled porridges require larger pellets because they are less likely to disintegrate during the boiling process. The process of dampening, breaking up clumps and adding dry flour to keep the formed pellets from sticking must be repeated until all the millet flour has been converted to uniformly-sized millet-flour pellets. Scrape off flour from the bowl edges. During this process, the millet flour will adhere to the calabash gourd walls, so scrape this off. Note: Metal bowls usually do not develop a build-up. Finish up and make use of the millet pellets. In this case, only one size of pellet is required, so there are no sifting steps required. This process has produced in less than one hour of steady hand-working, about 5 kg of millet flour pellets suitable for a popular West African millet porridge. These millet pellets are ready to be sent to the kitchen to boil, put in the refrigerator (up to a week) or frozen for use some other day.
